courses.name: Rise of China as a Global Power

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will take students through important domestic institutions and events in China that shape its current political landscape. Students will be prompted to think about the implications of domestic political factors for China’s rise as a global power. The course examines major China’s adventurism abroad, such as the Belt-and-Road Initiative, and what increasing footprints of Chinese state and private firms overseas mean for international politics. (Given by the Department of Political Science and the Contemporary Asian Studies Program)
cmCourseInfo.title: Rise of China as a Global Power
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 credits in POL/ JPA/ JPF/ JPI/ JPR/ JPS/ JRA courses, or 1.0 CAS credit
publicationSections: Contemporary Asian Studies, Dr. David Chu Program in

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Prerequisites/Exclusions:

  • Prerequisites and exclusions are enforced for all POL courses.  Please consult the Faculty of Arts and Science Calendar https://artsci.calendar.utoronto.ca/section/Political-Science, or the POL Undergraduate website https://politics.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/fallwinter-timetable/ for details.
  • Students will be removed from this course if they do not have the prerequisite as stated in the Faculty of Arts and Science Calendar.

       

Note:

  • If you do have the background preparation to take this course, please contact the instructor for permission to waive the prerequisite before enrolling in the course.
  • If permission is granted by the instructor, please forward the email to the Undergraduate Assistant at undergrad.polsci@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the politics of authoritarianism in theory and practice. It covers major theories in authoritarian politics, ranging from selectorate theory, authoritarian institutions, impact of institutions on political outcome, ways of measuring authoritarian state power, democracy and development, to social movement and state repression in authoritarian regime, and political transitions. On empirical application, we will draw on cases from around the world, with some emphasis on Asian authoritarian states. (Given by the Department of Political Science and the Contemporary Asian Studies Program)
cmCourseInfo.title: Authoritarianism in Comparative Perspective
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 2.0 credits in POL/ JPA/ JPF/ JPI/ JPR/ JPS/ JRA/ CAS courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

POL 400-level Enrolment

  • This 400-level course is part of the POL pre-enrolment.
  • Eligible POL Specialist and Major program students will receive via email in May 2024 the detail information to rank their POL 400-level courses in order of preference between June 1 to June 15, 2024.
  • Decisions will be confirmed on ACORN the day before registration begins.
  • Students who are not pre-enrolled in a course but meet the enrolment controls will be able to enrol (or waitlist) for the course once course enrolment begins in July.

 

Prerequisites/Exclusions

  • Prerequisites and exclusions are enforced for all POL courses.  Please consult the Faculty of Arts and Science Calendar https://artsci.calendar.utoronto.ca/section/Political-Science , or the POL Undergraduate website https://politics.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/fallwinter-timetable/ for details.
  • Students will be removed from this course if they do not have the prerequisite as stated in the Faculty of Arts and Science Calendar.

Note:

  • If you do have the background preparation to take this course, please contact the instructor for permission to waive the prerequisite before enrolling in the course.
  • If permission is granted by the instructor, please forward the email to the Undergraduate Assistant at undergrad.polsci@utoronto.ca.
